sentences: Travis Tatum Mills (born April 12, 1989), previously known by his stage name T. Mills, is an American rapper, singer, and actor from Riverside, California.

sentences: Following his name change from T. Mills to Travis Mills, he began hosting an eponymous show on Apple Music 1.

== Career == | === 2011–2012: Signing to Columbia Records, Leaving Home and MtvU's Woodie Awards ===

sentences: In 2011, Mills signed a deal to Columbia Records, following him signing a deal, he began recording his second and first major-label album.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2012: Signing to Columbia Records, Leaving Home and MtvU's Woodie Awards ===

sentences: On July 22, 2011, Mills released a mixtape, titled Leaving Home.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2012: Signing to Columbia Records, Leaving Home and MtvU's Woodie Awards ===

sentences: Leaving Home is a 10-track project, with no guest appearances, while the production was provided from Noel Zancalla, Omen, AudioBlack, The Futuristics, Colin Munroe and Phonix, among others.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2012: Signing to Columbia Records, Leaving Home and MtvU's Woodie Awards ===

sentences: On December 6, 2011, Mills announced that he would be repackaged as a 5-track EP, under its same name as his mixtape through Columbia Records.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2012: Signing to Columbia Records, Leaving Home and MtvU's Woodie Awards ===

sentences: The EP's lead single, called "Vans On" was released on December 12, 2011, along with the promotional single, called "The Boom".
section: == Career == | === 2011–2012: Signing to Columbia Records, Leaving Home and MtvU's Woodie Awards ===

sentences: The EP was made available for retail stores on December 13, 2011.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2012: Signing to Columbia Records, Leaving Home and MtvU's Woodie Awards ===

sentences: On December 15, 2011, to promote the release of the EP, he performed at The Roxy Show in Los Angeles, California.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2012: Signing to Columbia Records, Leaving Home and MtvU's Woodie Awards ===

sentences: The EP was released for free on December 19, 2011, The EP was officially released on January 13, 2012, featuring some added new tracks, while the additional production was provided from Sir Nolan and The Stereotypes, among others.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2012: Signing to Columbia Records, Leaving Home and MtvU's Woodie Awards ===

sentences: In March 2012, Mills was nominated for the Best New Artist at the MtvU's Woodie Awards.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2012: Signing to Columbia Records, Leaving Home and MtvU's Woodie Awards ===

sentences: On July 23, 2012, Mills released his second mixtape, called Thrillionaire.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2012: Signing to Columbia Records, Leaving Home and MtvU's Woodie Awards ===

sentences: It contains 10 tracks, featuring three guest appearances from American rapper Smoke DZA, the hip hop duo Audio Push, and an American musician James Fauntleroy II; as well as the production from Sledgren, The Monsters & Strangerz and Kane Beatz, among others.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2012: Signing to Columbia Records, Leaving Home and MtvU's Woodie Awards ===

sentences: To promote the mixtape release, Mills filmed some music videos for songs such as "Lightweight", "Diemonds" and "Other Bitch Callin'" featuring James Fauntleroy II.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2012: Signing to Columbia Records, Leaving Home and MtvU's Woodie Awards ===

sentences: Mills later announced that he is planning on releasing the sequel for his second mixtape, called Thrillionaire 2.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2012: Signing to Columbia Records, Leaving Home and MtvU's Woodie Awards ===

sentences: : SummerFest and All I Wanna Do ===
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: SummerFest and All I Wanna Do ===

sentences: In 2013, Mills announced that the release date for his second major-label album has been slated for the second quarter of 2013.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: SummerFest and All I Wanna Do ===

sentences: It was reported that Mills was working on his second major-label album with artists such as Juicy J, Mike Posner, James Fauntleroy, Travis Barker, Layzie Bone and Skeme, with the production by Mills himself, alongside several other record producers such as Kane Beatz, 1500 or Nothin', Malay and Boi-1da, among others.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: SummerFest and All I Wanna Do ===

sentences: On February 15, 2013, Mills announced that his first single for his second major-label album will be coming soon.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: SummerFest and All I Wanna Do ===

sentences: On March 5, 2013, the audio for his song, called "Loud" was released for digital download.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: SummerFest and All I Wanna Do ===

sentences: The following day, Mills released the music video for "Loud".
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: SummerFest and All I Wanna Do ===

sentences: The song was produced by Pop Wansel, and the song contains a sample of "I Know You Got Soul" performed by Eric B. and Rakim.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: SummerFest and All I Wanna Do ===

sentences: He later said that "the hook for the song was one of his favorites out of all the hooks, he has ever written".
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: SummerFest and All I Wanna Do ===

sentences: In April 2013, Mills was touring with a fellow American rapper Sammy Adams.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: SummerFest and All I Wanna Do ===

sentences: On June 27, 2013, Mills was featured on Mike Posner's remix to "We Own It (Fast & Furious)", along with Sammy Adams and Niykee Heaton.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: SummerFest and All I Wanna Do ===

sentences: In June 2013, Mills was on tour with We the Kings, and the fellow supporting acts The Ready Set and Breathe Carolina on the 2013's SummerFest.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: SummerFest and All I Wanna Do ===

sentences: The music video for the single, called "All I Wanna Do", was shot and filmed in July 2013.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: SummerFest and All I Wanna Do ===

sentences: On February 18, 2014, Mills announced the release to his third EP, titled All I Wanna Do.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: SummerFest and All I Wanna Do ===

sentences: Starting from February 24 to April 24, 2014, Mills will be headlining on his All I Wanna Do Tour.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: SummerFest and All I Wanna Do ===

sentences: On February 24, 2014, while starting his promotional tour for his third EP, Mills released the audio to its title track "All I Wanna Do".
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: SummerFest and All I Wanna Do ===

sentences: The following day, Mills officially released the All I Wanna Do EP, via iTunes.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: SummerFest and All I Wanna Do ===

sentences: The EP features production from Boi-1da and Malay, among others.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: SummerFest and All I Wanna Do ===

sentences: In July 2015, Mills would change his stage name to his artistic name Travis Mills.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: SummerFest and All I Wanna Do ===

sentences: On July 24, 2015, Travis released his new single, titled "Young & Stupid".

sentences: In 2020, Mills formed the band Girlfriends with Nick Gross, with the duo citing Blink-182, 5 Seconds of Summer and All Time Low as the band's musical influences.

== Musical style ==

sentences: Musical style ==
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: Mills' music has been described as genre-blending due to his mix of singing and rapping, being mostly labeled as a hip hop and synthpop artist.
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: He is known for mixing pop and electronic songs with hip hop and R&B.
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: Mills says that his genre-blending music is a result of his exposure to many different genres during childhood.
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: He has said that "[my] mom was a huge Queen fan, my dad's a diehard Elvis fan, my uncle is a hip-hop and R&B head, my sister listened to Britney Spears, country and boy bands and I was into pop punk, punk rock, metal and just into everything."
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: He indicated that his rapping style was influenced by Kanye West and Bone Thugs-n-Harmony, among others.
section: == Musical style ==

== Personal life ==

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Mills is heavily tattooed, which includes a full sleeve on one arm and a Bone Thugs-n-Harmony tattoo on his chest, in addition to many others.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: He also designated the letters "FTH" ("Fuck The Haters", "Forever The Highest") on his forehead, the "O" with a heart behind his left ear representing his sisters name and the word "Patience" tatted on his knuckles.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Mills also got the word "Gnarly" tattooed across his stomach at age 18.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: A couple months after that he gave himself a tattoo.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Early in his career Mills sported large stretched earlobes, but proceeded with lobe reconstruction surgery in 2013.
